content: Write a scene from a play set in a busy New York City restaurant. The main characters are a waitress having her first day at work and a regular customer known for being particularly difficult.

(Setting: A bustling New York City restaurant during the dinner rush. Tables are filled with patrons, and the air is thick with the scent of cooking food and conversations. The waitress, JESSICA, is new to the job, looking slightly overwhelmed but determined. She approaches a table occupied by MR. HARRIS, a regular customer with a reputation for being difficult.)

JESSICA: (Approaching the table with a nervous smile) Good evening, Mr. Harris. I'm Jessica, your server for tonight. Can I start you off with something to drink?

MR. HARRIS: (Looking up from his newspaper, eyes narrowing) Oh, it's you. New girl, huh? Well, let's see what you're made of. I'll have my usual— a dry martini, shaken, not stirred, with a twist of lemon. And make it snappy.

JESSICA: (Nods, trying to hide her anxiety) Alright, a dry martini, shaken, not stirred, with a lemon twist. I'll get that right out for you.

(Moves away to the bar to place the order, trying to remember the specifics.)

(Bartender, TOM, notices her hesitation.)

TOM: Need a hand there, Jessica? First day can be tough.

JESSICA: Yeah, thanks, Tom. Mr. Harris wants a dry martini, shaken, not stirred, with a lemon twist.

TOM: Got it. Don't worry about him; he's all talk. Just make sure you get his drink right, and the rest will fall into place.

JESSICA: Okay, thanks. (Takes the drink back to Mr. Harris)

JESSICA: Here's your martini, Mr. Harris. I hope it meets your standards.

MR. HARRIS: (Tasting it) Hmm, not bad. You remember my preferences. Maybe you're not completely incompetent.

JESSICA: (Trying to keep her composure) Thank you. I'll be back to take your dinner order in a bit.

(Moves to another table to take orders, coming back to Mr. Harris.)

JESSICA: Ready to order, Mr. Harris?

MR. HARRIS: Actually, yes. I'll have the steak, rare, with a side of baked potatoes and steamed broccoli.

JESSICA: Steak, rare, with baked potatoes and steamed broccoli. Anything else?

MR. HARRIS: Oh, and make sure the steak is perfectly cooked. I don't like my meat overdone.

JESSICA: No problem, I'll make sure the kitchen knows it's rare.

(Makes a note and heads back to the kitchen to place the order.)

(Kitchen is chaotic, with chefs shouting orders.)

JESSICA: (To the chef) Steak for Mr. Harris, rare, baked potatoes, and steamed broccoli.

CHEF: Got it, Jessica. We'll take care of it.

(Jessica returns to Mr. Harris's table.)

JESSICA: Your order has been placed, Mr. Harris. It should be out shortly.

MR. HARRIS: Good. And make sure everything is up to my standards.

JESSICA: Of course, sir.

(As Jessica is attending to other tables, Mr. Harris calls her back.)

MR. HARRIS: Hey, Jessica, I need some more water.

JESSICA: (Hurrying over) Oh, sorry, I must have forgotten. Let me get that for you right now.

(Brings water and checks on him periodically.)

(Finally, the food is ready.)

JESSICA: (Bringing the plate) Here's your steak, Mr. Harris. I hope you enjoy it.

MR. HARRIS: (Cutting into the steak) Perfectly rare. You did well this time.

JESSICA: I'm glad you like it. Is there anything else I can get for you?

MR. HARRIS: No, for now, that's all.

(Jessica moves to other tables, but Mr. Harris calls her back again.)

MR. HARRIS: Jessica, my broccoli seems a bit overcooked.

JESSICA: I'm sorry to hear that, sir. Let me get you a fresh side right away.

(Makes a note and brings back new broccoli.)

MR. HARRIS: That's better. Now, that's what I'm talking about.

JESSICA: I'm glad you're satisfied, Mr. Harris.

(Later, as the dinner rush starts to die down.)

JESSICA: (Approaching Mr. Harris again) Is there anything else I can get for you before I close your check?

MR. HARRIS: Actually, yes. I need my check, please.

JESSICA: Right away, sir.

(Brings the check.)

MR. HARRIS: (Looking it over) This looks correct. (Pauses) You know, for a new girl, you did okay tonight.

JESSICA: Thank you, sir. I appreciate the compliment.

MR. HARRIS: Just remember, in this business, it's all about attention to detail and remembering the regulars' preferences.

JESSICA: I will, thank you for the advice.

(Mr. Harris leaves, and Jessica lets out a sigh of relief.)

JESSICA: (To herself) That wasn't so bad.

(Tom approaches her.)

TOM: How'd it go with Mr. Harris?

JESSICA: Surprisingly well, I think. He was tough, but I managed.

TOM: See, I told you, he's all talk. You did great for your first day.

JESSICA: Thanks, Tom. I couldn't have done it without your help.

TOM: Anytime, kid. Welcome to the team.

(They share a smile as the restaurant continues to buzz around them.)

(End of Scene)
